title: Bangladesh  Village life documentary in Urdu and Hindi

subtasks: Walk through the rows of crops in the field
Check for signs of pests or disease
Note any unusually affected plants
Enter data into precision agriculture software
Adjust the settings on the farm equipment
Test the machinery to ensure accurate application
Lay out pipes and hoses for water distribution
Connect components and check for leaks
Program irrigator timing according to crop needs
Load the equipment with the appropriate chemicals
Operate the sprayer or spreader to apply the substances
Monitor coverage and adjust application as needed
Kneel or squat to reach between plants
Remove weeds by hand, ensuring not to damage crops
Disposed of weeds properly
Bend over or crouch to reach low-hanging fruits
Clip or cut the produce from the plants
Sort and place the harvested items into containers
Bend down and lift the produce into the vehicle
Secure the load to prevent shifting during transport
Tiller the soil to aerate and mix in organic matter
Spray or spread soil amendments as required
Plant seeds at the appropriate depth and spacing
Check the condition of barn or shed structures
Refill feed and water troughs
Examine animals for signs of illness or injury
Mix seeds with a carrier or fertilizer
Drill the seeds into the ground using a planter
Cover the planted area with mulch or straw

tasks.task: Drive tractors and other farm vehicles
subtasks: Board the tractor seat, secure straps
Operate the steering, gears, and hydraulics
Navigate the fields safely and efficiently
Maintain speed appropriate for the task
Inspect machines for wear or damage
Lubricate moving parts as needed
Replace any missing parts or blades
Handle the animals to load them onto the transport vehicle
Secure the animals inside to prevent escape
Monitor the health of the animals during transit
Slaughter the animals in a humane manner
Skin, eviscerate, and age the carcasses
Cut and package the meat for sale
Measure the area required for fencing
Assemble the fence posts and wires
Drive stakes into the ground securely
String the wires to the correct tension
Use a goatherd or similar tool to move animals
Keep the animals contained during movement
Ensure smooth and safe passage through gates
Open the coop or chicken run
Gather eggs from the nesting boxes
Clean the eggs as needed and place them in a basket
Mix and measure out the feed rations
Distribute the feed evenly to the animals
Refill water sources daily
Position the ride mower or mower-conditioner
Start the engine and set the cutting height
Navigate the rows, maintaining a straight path
Adjust the swath width and repeat as necessary
Attach the cultivator implements to the tractor
Plow the rows to disrupt weed growth
Level the soil after cultivation
Pre-pack or arrange the produce in displays
Price and label items for sale
Communicate with customers or wait staff
Measure and cut the mulch film to the field dimensions
Pull the mulch strips through the field using equipment
Roll out the mulch and secure the edges
Saw or shear overgrown branches
Clear the area around the structures or planting beds
Mark the course of the water channel
Use a shovel or plow to dig the ditch
Straighten the bottom and sides of the ditch
Use hand tools or specialized picking machinery
Collect the ripe crop from the field
Organize the collected produce for further processing
Measure and mark the placement for the gates
Fasten the gate posts securely into the ground
Attach horizontal bars and hinges to create the gate
Use a moisture meter to test various spots in the field
Record the readings for future reference or adjustment
Compare the data to the crop’s water requirements
Walk the perimeter of the property with measuring tools
Note boundaries, existing structures, and topography
Use a GPS or surveying app to document the layout
Park the vehicle in a suitable parking area
Enter the conference venue and find a seat
Take notes during the presentations or workshops
Network with other farmers or industry professionals
Review historical yield data for each field
Consider pest and disease pressures, soil health
Draft a rotation schedule for the upcoming season
Mix the chemical solution according to labels
Spray the plants with the regulator, targeting the correct stages
Evaluate the treated area for effectiveness
Determine the layout and number of trees needed
Prepare the ground by tilling and adding amendments
Plant the selected windbreak species
Water and protect the seedlings until established
Set up the piping and frame for the shade house
Cover with appropriate shade cloth or netting
Secure the edges and anchors
Check for stability in windy conditions
Use loppers or shears to remove excessive growth
Maintain the desired shape for optimal sun exposure
Prune dead or diseased branches
Stump the remaining canes before new growth
Collect soil samples from different areas of the field
Send samples to a lab for nutrient analysis
Interpret the results and plan amendments
Assign tasks to workers based on their expertise
Schedule shifts and breaks to comply with regulations
Communicate deadlines and expectations clearly
Identify the source of the malfunction
Gather replacement parts from the storage
Disassemble the damaged components and reassemble correctly
Inspect the vehicle’s exterior for damage
Test all mechanical systems, including brakes and fluids
Change the oil and filter as necessary
Check tire pressure and rotate tires if needed
Clean and lubricate the machinery
Protect mechanical parts against rust and cold with appropriate coatings
Secure implements for the season to prevent damage
Keep a daily log of feed intake and waste production
Conduct temperature checks or look for specific symptoms
Adjust feed or medication as needed based on health status
Clean the udder and teats thoroughly
Attach the milking machine and let down the milk
Collect the milk in a sanitized container
Check for signs of mastitis or other issues
Harvest the crop when it reaches the appropriate moisture level
Chop the crop into small pieces using a chopper
Pack the material tightly into silo structures
Cover the top to minimize air exposure
Communicate the problem to the appropriate staff member
Remove the malfunctioning equipment from the field if safe
Summon a repair service or call the manufacturer's support
Attach the manure spreader to the tractor
Apply the manure to the fields, ensuring even distribution
Avoid over-application in any one area to prevent runoff
Remove manure and soiled bedding from the coop
Disinfect the interior surfaces with appropriate solutions
Re-fill the feed and water stations
Broadcast the fertilizer over the field using a spreader
Adjust the machine’s width and speed to cover the area uniformly
Overlap and check for skips or dense areas
Research current prices and demand for different crops
Analyze competitors’ offerings and pricing strategies
Update business plans with new financial projections
Install the drip lines through the field
Connect to the main water supply and pressure regulator
Test the system for leaks and ensure proper flow rates
Turn the compost pile regularly to aerate the mixture
Check the moisture and carbon-to-nitrogen ratio
Harvest the finished compost and use it in the gardens or fields
Grapple the bale with a forklift and deposit onto the ground
Use a dolly or special equipment to move the bale into the storage
Stagger the bales to allow airflow and prevent moisture buildup
Inject vaccinations or administer antibiotics
Apply dust mites or other external parasiticides
Take careful notes on treatments given and revaccinate as necessary
Divide the pasture into paddocks using temporary fencing
Rotate the livestock to fresh grazing areas regularly
Monitor the rate of grass consumption and adjust grazing times
Spray the fields with a backpack sprayer handheld
Wear the appropriate personal protective equipment
Stay downwind and walk perpendicular to the wind direction
Monitor coverage and adjust the nozzle position as needed
Enter the combine and adjust settings for the type of crop
Harvest the field by driving the combine through the rows
Separate the grain from the chaff and store it safely
Arrange tables and displays for the produce
Prepare promotional materials and marketing signs
Greet customers and take their orders
Process transactions and pack purchases into bags
Plow the field to break up the soil and remove debris
Rotary till the soil to incorporate amendments and manage residue
Create furrows or ridges as needed for planting orientation
Fill the sprayer with the desired chemical solution
Calibrate the nozzle tips for the correct spray pattern
Operate the sprayer while moving through the field, maintaining the specified speed
Apply the spray evenly without overlapping too much or too little
Ascend to the desired height on the cherry picker
Collect the ripe fruits from high branches
Ensure safety by using the proper harness and positioning
Mix the seed with a fungicide or other protectants
Use a seed meter or planter to apply the treated seed
Monitor the application rate and ensure even distribution
Use a dehydrator or hang the produce in a well-ventilated area
Monitor the moisture content and timing for removal
Store the dried product properly to avoid contamination
Dig the appropriate hole for the root ball
Carefully lower the plant into the hole, ensuring it is plumb
Backfill with soil mixed with amendments
Water thoroughly and mulch around the base
Push a probe into the ground to measure bulk density
Take notes on the ease of penetration for future tillage
Compare to standard tests or resources
Arrange the feed in the bins or silos
Check expiration dates and rotate stock as needed
Inventory weekly to avoid stockouts
Assemble the drill and secure the appropriate seeds
Drive the implements across the field, planting at the correct depth
Overlap rows slightly to ensure coverage and minimal gaps
Fertilize and lime the pasture areas
Plant or overseed with grasses suitable for horses
Mow and maintain the pasture regularly
Outline the goals and strategies for the upcoming year
Include financial projections, marketing plans, and operations
Get input from advisors and finalise the document

tasks.task: Conduct a soil test for pH
subtasks: Collect a composite sample from various parts of the field
Send the sample to a testing lab
Interpret the pH result and plan lime applications if necessary
Cut the hay at the proper stage and immediately wilt it
Pack into a silo or tube for anaerobic fermentation
Seal the silo to prevent oxygen from entering
Tidy the land, tilling if necessary, to make it ready for sowing
Arrange seed in rows or blocks according to the crop type
Firm the seedbed by raking or rolling
Hang carcasses in a temperature-controlled cooler
Check daily for optimal aging conditions (humidity and temperature)
Condition the meat by allowing it to rest before cutting
Mix the fertilizer concentrate with water according to PPM
Use a boom sprayer to evenly distribute the solution over the crop
Maintain precise application rates without over-spraying
Lay out the drip irrigation tubing through the rows
Connect the pipes to the main water supply
Secure the connections with appropriate clamps or connectors
Test the irrigation system during the off-peak hour to check timing
Inspect automated gates or barriers for proper operation
Ensure remote controls function correctly
Weigh individual animals or groups at regular intervals
Collect data on growth rates, feed efficiency, etc.
Compare to breed standards and adjust feeding as needed
Identify electrical components that need grounding
Check the condition of grounding rods and conductors
Test the efficacy with a ground tester and re-ground if necessary
Inspect beehives for swarm activity or illness
Feed or re-queen if needed
Take protective measures when handling the hives
Affix tags to the trunks of new plantings for identification
Use a deadbolt glue that sets quickly
Space tags far enough to not interfere with trunk growth
Measure the area of a representative sample
Assess the number of harvestable units per unit area
Multiply to estimate total production
Collect a sample from the animal for diagnostic testing
Discuss treatment options with a veterinarian
Administer medications after approval, if necessary
Consider soil type, temperature, and evapotranspiration rates
Schedule irrigations based on crop development stages
Log the timing and volume of each event for monitoring
Select native species for windbreak or erosion control
Prepare the planting beds, adding organic matter if needed
Space plants properly for mature size and prune for structure
Walk the fields looking for signs of premature ripening or disease
Sample-crop and test for maturity or contamination
Organize harvesting plans based on the findings
Gather data on current land values, size, and boundaries
Use online resources or consult with a real estate agent
Determine fair market value for potential purchase or sale
Inspect belts, chains, and other moving parts for wear
Grease or replace hydraulic seals
Check the air and oil filters and change them if necessary
Weigh or measure the active ingredients according to label directions
Dilute the concentrate in water using a measuring device
Pour the mixture into a spray tank, label the container
Apply herbicides, insecticides, or fungicides as needed
Evaluate the effect of the application and adjust treatments if necessary
Document application dates and rates for record-keeping
Erect or reinforce fencing near critical areas
Use predator deterrents, such as scarecrows or motion sensors
Conduct regular inspections to monitor effectiveness
Remove dead or crossing branches
Thin the fruit to improve yield and quality
Sharpen pruning shears before starting
Apply a fungicide or dormant oil spray after pruning
Position the straw bales close together with minimal gaps
Use wire mesh support around the bales for a stable structure
Cover the exterior with siding or paint for durability
Track the development stages of the crops (e.g., bud break, flowering)
Adjust management practices as the crop progresses
Share observations with extension agents or record in a journal
Test shovels, rakes, and other manual tools for sharpness or needing replacement
Oil and store tools properly to extend their life
Replace any damaged or missing components
Evaluate the capacity and durability of existing storage structures
Design or source new storage units based on future needs
Schedule construction or ordering for the next planting season
Mix cover crop species with fertilizer if necessary
Distribute the seed evenly over the surface of the field
Set the cultipacker to press the seed into the soil
Identify non-native or problematic plants
Choose the appropriate method for control (mowing, herbicide)
Apply treatment appropriately and monitor outcomes
Disassemble machinery after use to remove debris
Rinse with water or sanitizing solution
Lubricate moving parts and store in a dry place
Inspect PPE (个人防护装备) for wear or tear
Test emergency stop buttons on equipment
Review OSHA compliance and facility safety
Mix well-aged compost with soil amendments
Broadcast or band apply the compost to the growing area
Confirm no hot spots or over-concentrations
Categorize and file paperwork related to production, finances, and permits
Input data into a computer or spreadsheet system
Back up data regularly to prevent loss
Install the netting over crops to prevent pecking
Attach to existing posts or replace damaged supports
Tack or staple the edges securely to the ground
Check traps or visual inspections for pest activity
Take samples to a lab for identification and population assessment
Plan control measures based on survey results

tasks.task: Plan and implement a rotational grazing system
subtasks: Divide the pasture into paddocks with appropriate fencing
Create a schedule for moving livestock among the different areas
Monitor animal behavior and make adjustments as needed
Pick the ripe produce from the indoor plants
Sort and clean the harvested items
Deliver to storage or market promptly
Test the gate hinges and latches for strength
Repair any rusted areas or broken parts
Test the gate’s operation in both open and closed positions
Schedule regular deep soak irrigation for trees and established crops
Spaced shallower irrigations for seedlings and annuals
Adapt based on weather forecasts and soil moisture
Use GPS and yield monitor on the combine during harvest
Record and adjust inputs and irrigation according to yield data
Analyze results quarterly to make informed decisions.
ALL MAINTASK AND SUBTASKS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED.

rates for record-keeping MAINTASK: Secure livestock from wildlife SUBTASK: Erect or reinforce fencing near critical areas SUBTASK: Use predator deterrents, such as scarecrows or motion sensors SUBTASK: Conduct regular inspections to monitor effectiveness MAINTASK: Prune orchard trees SUBTASK: Remove dead or crossing branches SUBTASK: Thin the fruit to improve yield and quality SUBTASK: Sharpen pruning shears before starting SUBTASK: Apply a fungicide or dormant oil spray after pruning MAINTASK: Apply straw bale houses SUBTASK: Position the straw bales close together with minimal gaps SUBTASK: Use wire mesh support around the bales for a stable structure SUBTASK: Cover the exterior with siding or paint for durability MAINTASK: Conduct phenological observations SUBTASK: Track the development stages of the crops (e.g., bud break, flowering) SUBTASK: Adjust management practices as the crop progresses SUBTASK: Share observations with extension agents or record in a journal MAINTASK: Inspect tool functionality SUBTASK: Test shovels, rakes, and other manual tools for sharpness or needing replacement SUBTASK: Oil and store tools properly to extend their life SUBTASK: Replace any damaged or missing components MAINTASK: Plan storage solutions SUBTASK: Evaluate the capacity and durability of existing storage structures SUBTASK: Design or source new storage units based on future needs SUBTASK: Schedule construction or ordering for the next planting season MAINTASK: Apply cover crop seed SUBTASK: Mix cover crop species with fertilizer if necessary SUBTASK: Distribute the seed evenly over the surface of the field SUBTASK: Set the cultipacker to press the seed into the soil MAINTASK: Manage pasture weeds SUBTASK: Identify non-native or problematic plants SUBTASK: Choose the appropriate method for control (mowing, herbicide) SUBTASK: Apply treatment appropriately and monitor outcomes MAINTASK: Clean processing equipment SUBTASK: Disassemble machinery after use to remove debris SUBTASK: Rinse with water or sanitizing solution SUBTASK: Lubricate moving parts and store in a dry place MAINTASK: Conduct a safety check SUBTASK: Inspect PPE (personal protective equipment) for wear or tear SUBTASK: Test emergency stop buttons on equipment SUBTASK: Review OSHA compliance and facility safety MAINTASK: Prepare and apply manure compost SUBTASK: Mix well-aged compost with soil amendments SUBTASK: Broadcast or band apply the compost to the growing area SUBTASK: Confirm no hot spots or over-concentrations MAINTASK: Organize farm records SUBTASK: Categorize and file paperwork related to production, finances, and permits SUBTASK: Input data into a computer or spreadsheet system SUBTASK: Back up data regularly to prevent loss MAINTASK: Apply bird netting SUBTASK: Install the netting over crops to prevent pecking SUBSTITUTE edges STTICKY: ATTACH to existing posts or replace damaged supports SUBTASK: Test the netting’s stability and secureness MAINTASK: Conduct surveys for pest infestations SUBTASK: Check traps or visual inspections for pest activity SUBTASK: Take samples to a lab for identification and population assessment SUBTASK:Plan control measures based on survey results MAINTASK: Plan and implement a rotational grazing system SUBTASK: Divide the pasture into paddocks with appropriate fencing SUBTASK: Create a schedule for moving livestock among the different areas SUBTASK: Monitor animal behavior and make adjustments as needed MAINTASK: Harvest greenhouse crops SUBTASK: Pick the ripe produce from the indoor plants SUBTASK: Sort and clean the harvested items SUBTASK: Deliver to storage or market promptly MAINTASK: Repair livestock handling gates SUBTASK: Test the gate hinges and latches for strength SUBTASK: Repair any rusted areas or broken parts SUBTASK: Test the gate's operation in both open and closed positions MAINTASK: Plan irrigation schedules SUBTASK: Schedule regular deep soak irrigation for trees and established crops SUBTASK: Apply shallower irrigations for seedlings and annuals SUBTASK: Adapt based on weather forecasts and soil moisture MAINTASK: Conduct yield monitoring SUBTASK: Use GPS and yield monitor on the combine during harvest SUBTASK: Record and adjust inputs and irrigation according to yield data SUBTASK: Analyze results quarterly to make informed decisions.
